title: ‘Selfish’ pensioner whose dying wife was found covered in maggots is jailed
text:
Richard Wallach has now been jailed for eight years

A man who left his wife to die in squalid conditions after neglecting her has been jailed.

Richard Wallach, 67, failed to look after his wife, Valerie, to the point that emergency services found her covered in maggots and flies.

Her armchair was soaked in urine and she was riddled with skin ulcers, a court was told.

Medical professionals said Mrs Wallach was found in the ‘worst condition of a living human they had seen’.

Wallach was found guilty of manslaughter through gross negligence and sentenced to eight years in jail at Liverpool Crown Court.

He stared ahead as Judge Neil Flewitt QC told him: ‘You are a thoroughly selfish man, and in this instance your selfishness led to the death of your wife.’

Valerie Wallach died in hospital after neglect from her husband of 25 years (Picture: Liverpool Echo)

A jury was told that Mrs Wallach, 61, had been sitting in a chair for months and was so ill when paramedics found her she could no longer speak.

She was covered in faeces and there were maggots in the folds of her skin.

The mum-of-two died 19 days after being admitted to hospital after being diagnosed with advanced breast cancer, organ failure, pressure sores and sepsis.

Mrs Wallach finally received vital care after her husband went to the Elms Medical Centre in on August 24 2017 and told them his wife was ill.

He claimed he had been unable to call an ambulance as he did not have a telephone.

Firefighters were eventually called to the home in Toxteth, Liverpool on August 24, 2017.

Wallach had objected to them removing a window because he was worried about the insurance, the jury was told.

Richard Wallach from Toxteth was convicted at Liverpool Crown Court (Picture: Liverpool Echo)

At hospital when he was told his wife’s prognosis was poor, he showed no concern instead worrying more about himself.

The court heard he replied: ‘Thanks for letting me know, but who is going to sort out my problem?

‘I have been constipated for weeks.’

Horrific images from the couple’s home showed the grim conditions Mrs Wallach deteriorated in.

Rubbish and unopened mail littered the hallway that led into the living room where she was left to die in her armchair.

Piles of papers, Pot Noodle packaging and filled bin bags covered every surface surrounding the brown leather Chesterfield which was reportedly soiled.

Images show the conditions Richard and Valerie Wallach lived in at their home on Gwendoline Street, in Toxteth (Picture: Liverpool Echo)

Neighbours said they were shocked at what had happened and were entirely unaware.

Advertisement

One, who did not wish to be named, said: ‘They just seemed like nice people, you would not think something like that would have happened.

‘We’re just shocked. If that had happened to anybody, you’d be shocked, but if it’s someone that lives on your street and you’ve known them, you just can’t explain it.’

Wallach had denied the charge of manslaughter through gross negligence.

He said he would see his wife several times a day and would give her sandwiches and takeaway which she would feed herself.

He told detectives: ‘We were together for 25 years and I loved the bones of her.’

Wallach was diagnosed with a hoarding disorder (Picture: Liverpool Echo)

In court, his QC David McLachlan asked if he was responsible for his wife’s death he replied, ‘I take offence at that. I am not guilty for the death of my wife, no way.’

Wallach, who was found by a psychiatrist to be suffering from ‘hoarding’ disorder, was also shown photographs of his wife in hospital.

He admitted the injuries were ‘very bad. I must have had a mental lapse or something. I do not recall those injuries at all.’

He added: ‘I looked after her to the best of my ability.’
